awd_titl_txt: Measurement of inter-scale molecular fluxes in supercritical reacting turbulence
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding how fluctuations at a specific length scale in a turbulent flow affect the phenomena at other length scales is critical to accurately predict flow properties by numerical simulation. In turbulent combustion, which is the predominant mode of converting chemical energy to thermal energy for transportation and power generation applications, additional challenges arise in comparison to non-reacting turbulent flows because the fluctuating chemical reaction rates occur at very small length scales that typically are not resolved by simulations. This problem is exacerbated by the desire to operate combustion systems at increasingly high pressures, often spanning in to the supercritical pressure conditions. While increasing the pressure has important benefits for efficiency and power density, it also concentrates fluctuations at increasingly small scales and introduces strong variations in thermodynamic properties around the critical point. To better understand this phenomenon, this project will use a novel combination of laser diagnostic and data analysis techniques to measure how fluctuations in molecular nitrogen density move between length scales in premixed flames burning reactants at initially supercritical conditions.  

Time-resolved measurements of the spatially filtered nitrogen number density and velocity fields will be made in crossed planes using burst-mode spontaneous Raman scattering. The filtering effect of the observation process will be determined and tuned through image deconvolution. Hence, the resultant data will allow explicit determination of the flux of sub-filter fluctuations through the filter scale based on the dynamics of the filtered fields. This information will identify whether traditional modeling paradigms hold for supercritical reacting turbulence and, where necessary, enable the development of more physically accurate models. It also will provide a unique data set against which to benchmark simulations of supercritical turbulent combustion.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The objectives of this project were to:

  1. Create a new measurement technique that is capable of determining the instantaneous 2D spatial distribution of important chemical species in turbulent, chemically reacting flows with sufficient measurement frequency to resolve the dynamics.
  2. Create a unique "unit problem" experiment for turbulent combustion at high pressures (up to 50 bar), including detailed characterization of the boundary conditions.
  3. Deploy the measurement technique described above to acquire unique data of high-pressure flame chemical structure and dynamics.
  4. Use the resultant data to quantify important characteristics of the turbulent flame structure and dynamics, including flame thickness, curvature, corrugation scales, etc.

Such data are critical for developing and validating models needed for advanced computational simulations of combustion, particularly at the elevated pressures where most practical devices operate (e.g. jet engines, rockets, gas turbines, etc.).

To achieve these goals, we developed the first ever high-speed (10 kHz repetition-rate) planar laser Raman spectroscopy diagnostic that could be deployed in a high-pressure flame experiment. High-speed planar Raman scattering had only been demonstrated once before in a non-reacting mixing experiment, and very few demonstrations of low-speed planar Raman previously had been achieved. Key elements of our measurement system include a state-of-the-art pulse-burst laser, custom large-aperture achromatic lens, and custom high-speed 2D spectrometer capable of measuring Raman scattering signals from CH4, N2, H2O, and O2.We also created a unique high-pressure bluff-body stabilized flame experiment. The experimental apparatus is shown in the first figure.

The second figure shows the temporal and spatial evolution of bluff body stabilized flames at a particular fuel/air ratio, acquired at various chamber pressures. A steep gradient in intensity between 4 and 6 mm in the radial direction depicts the transition from the high temperature burnt gases to the low temperature unburnt reactant gases. These data reveal several important features of high-pressure turbulent flames that have never previously been measurable.

In addition to the primary goals of this project, we leveraged the effort to create a 1D Raman/Rayleigh scattering diagnostic system. This is one of only three comparable systems worldwide, with the others being at KAUST in Saudi Arabia and TU Darmstadt in Germany. Such a capability will have major impact on combustion research in the US. 

This project also helped support the development of a new Aerospace Propulsion Laboratory course at Georgia Tech. This course teaches first-year graduate students advanced laboratory skills, including LabView, lasers, optics, time-domain signal processing, plasma diagnostics, and several other topics. 


Last Modified: 12/20/2024
Modified by: Adam M Steinberg

Deploy the measurement technique described above to acquire unique data of high-pressure flame chemical structure and dynamics.
Use the resultant data to quantify important characteristics of the turbulent flame structure and dynamics, including flame thickness, curvature, corrugation scales, etc.



Such data are critical for developing and validating models needed for advanced computational simulations of combustion, particularly at the elevated pressures where most practical devices operate(e.g. jet engines, rockets, gas turbines, etc.).
